title: 108_s997
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the Middle Rio Grande bosque in Albuquerque, New Mexico is the largest continuous cottonwood forest in the Southwest, an old inhabited area, home to 6 pueblos, and a critical habitat for migratory birds. The area provides water to many in New Mexico and should be maintained to protect endangered species, the river flow, and be more accessible to the public. The Corps of Engineers should prioritize environmental restoration and reestablish hydrologic connections where possible. The Corps of Engineers should reestablish the hydrologic connection between the Middle Rio Grande and the Middle Rio Grande bosque to ensure healthy growth of native vegetation. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "critical restoration project" as a project that will provide immediate ecosystem restoration benefits, "Middle Rio Grande" as a specific portion of the Rio Grande in New Mexico, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Army. The Secretary will implement critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande based on feasibility studies and existing plans. Local entities involved in ecosystem restoration will be consulted for input. Cost-sharing agreements will be established before project implementation. Before carrying out critical restoration projects along the Middle Rio Grande, the Secretary will enter into cost-sharing agreements with non-Federal interests. These agreements will require non-Federal interests to contribute 25% of total project costs, provide necessary land and resources, cover operation and maintenance costs, and hold the United States harmless from any related claims or damages. The critical restoration project requires non-Federal interests to contribute 25% of total project costs, provide land and resources, cover operation and maintenance costs, and hold the United States harmless from any claims or damages. Recreational features in the project should not exceed 30% of the total cost, with non-Federal interests responsible for any additional costs. Non-Federal interests can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if approved by the Secretary. Non-Federal interests can receive credit towards their share of design or construction costs if approved by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2013.
